edge: A movie is represented by its summary.

D'Artagnan witnesses the murder of his parents at the hands of Febre, a cruel swordsman in the employ of Cardinal Richelieu. D'Artagnan is nearly killed after using his dead father's sword to attack Febre, who is then left with a permanent scar and the loss of his left eye.
The wounded boy is taken in by Planchet, a family friend and former member of the Musketeers.
Richelieu has ordered the disbandment of the Musketeers.
Richelieu plots to usurp the king's authority and render him a powerless figurehead.
Richelieu is trying to foment hostility between France, England, and Spain to gain more political power for himself.
Richelieu plots to usurp the king's authority and render him a powerless figurehead.
Richelieu realizes that the jingoistic Febre intends to incite full-blown war between England and France. Richelieu realizes that he has lost control of his chief henchman, Febre.
Febre kidnaps the queen.
The queen writes a letter to Buckingham asking him to meet her at a heavily fortified castle of his choosing, using the queen's ring to convince him of the authenticity of the message.
D'Artagnan and Francesca become intimate.
The landlord overhears d'Artagnan and Francesca and tells Febre.
D'Artagnan convinces two veteran musketeers, Porthos and Aramis, to free the imprisoned head of the musketeers, Captain de Tréville, thus earning their trust.
Febre incites a mob to attack the royal palace during a state dinner for Lord Buckingham, a visiting English dignitary.
Febre intends to incite full-blown war between England and France, threatening historical figures' responsibility to the crown.
Richelieu visits d'Artagnan and reveals Febre's plans, pleading for his help to stop him due to losing control of his chief henchman.
Febre is holding Francesca and d'Artagnan agrees to help stop him because of this.
D'Artagnan convinces the surviving musketeers that their responsibility to the crown remains their highest priority and they join him in stopping Febre.
Francesca, the queen, and Lord Buckingham are being held at the castle where d'Artagnan and the remaining musketeers charge on horseback to stop Febre.
The remaining musketeers easily deal with Febre's men while d'Artagnan engages Febre himself in an intense duel, finally killing him and avenging the death of his parents.
D'Artagnan covertly threatens Richelieu after stopping Febre.
D'Artagnan marries Francesca at the end of the film.
Both characters have similar portrayals as one-eyed men in black. This resemblance can be traced back to the 1973 film adaptation.
In this version, Febre takes precedence over the historical figures mentioned in the book.
The senior d'Artagnan was not a former musketeer, but his noble Gascon background encourages his son to enlist due to family traditions.
In this version, D'Artagnan bears witness to the gratuitous crime of his parents' murder, which is not part of Richelieu's conspiracy and neither Athos, Porthos nor Aramis are aware of it.

In this version, Planchet is not just a servant hired by D'Artagnan in Paris but rather a sidekick and mentor to the d'Artagnan family who raises the boy after his parents' death and arms himself with concealed pistols.
Skirmishes in the novel, simplified court intrigues in the film
Staging of public incidents to sap the King's credibility

Younger and more upbeat figure, niece instead of married to d'Artagnan's landlord
Invention in film, gentlemanly rivalry with d'Artagnan instead of outright villainous portrayal

The Three Musketeers adaptation, titled D'Artagnan, was one of several adaptations in the works at different studios at the time. The term 'adaptation' indicates that it is based on a pre-existing work, Alexander Dumas' novel.

Both the Three Musketeers adaptation being developed by Gene Quintano and Moshe Diamant, and Disney's adaptation received attention in the media at different times. This indicates that they are similar productions and can be seen as related.

Both the Three Musketeers adaptation being developed by Gene Quintano and Moshe Diamant, and Columbia's adaptation were in development around the same time. This indicates that they are similar productions and can be seen as related.

Both the Three Musketeers adaptation being developed by Gene Quintano and Moshe Diamant, and Tri-Star's adaptation were in development around the same time. This indicates that they are similar productions and can be seen as related.
Both Diamant's and Quintano's versions of the Three Musketeers adaptation were in development. This indicates that they are similar productions and can be seen as related.
Early coverage of the production named Mena Suvari as the lead actress, indicating that she was a significant figure in the project.
Both Gary Oldman and Mena Suvari were mentioned as potential cast members for the production, indicating that they were both significant figures in the project.
Early coverage of the production mentioned Michael Lonsdale as being in talks to appear, indicating that he was a significant figure in the project.
Peter Hyams replaced Gene Quintano as director of the production. This indicates a change in leadership and a potential shift in creative direction.
MDP Worldwide merged with Behaviour Communications to form a Canadian multimedia conglomerate, which was later renamed back to MDP Worldwide.
Catherine Deneuve signed on to star in Eyes Wide Shut shortly before filming, after being in negotiations for several months.
Eyes Wide Shut, FeardotCom, and Extreme Ops were all co-produced by MDP Worldwide, Luxembourg's Carousel Picture Company, and German tax shelter fund AppolloMedia.
Eyes Wide Shut was a co-production between the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, and Luxembourg.
Eyes Wide Shut was a co-production between the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, and Luxembourg's Carousel Picture Company.
MDP Worldwide was involved in producing both Eyes Wide Shut and FeardotCom, as well as Extreme Ops.

Despite interest from the local population, casting agents struggled to find suitable extras to portray a bygone peasantry, as most modern inhabitants of rural Southern France lacked the rough facial features desired by production, and looked too urban.
The streets of 17th century Paris were recreated in Sarlat-la-Canéda.
Another Dordogne locality, Monpazier, stood in for downtown Brionne.
Sarlat is featured in another adaptation of Dumas' work, Revenge of the Musketeers.
The Cité de Carcassonne provided wide shots of the French capital's now demolished fortifications.
The Royal Palace is based on the redecorated Capitole in Toulouse.
Richelieu's residence is based on the Convent of the Jacobins in Toulouse.
Château de Cassaigne is used as the domain where the Queen seeks shelter after escaping from Paris.
Château de Caumont in Cazaux-Savès stands in for the Musketeers' headquarters at Monsieur de Tréville's.

During filming in the area, Hyams, Diamant, Chambers, and Castaldi attended a ceremony at fr:Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Condom where they were made honorary 'musketeers', although this was not a military function, and rather a banquet organized by a cultural association only loosely related to the old Musketeers of the Guard.
Vianden Castle in Luxembourg became the fictional Duchamps Castle in the movie.
The film 'The Musketeer' is a reimagination of Alexandre Dumas's classic.
The film 'The Musketeer' held its world premiere in Los Angeles.
The film 'The Musketeer' held its European premiere at the Deauville Festival.
Universal released the film 'The Musketeer' in North America.
Miramax released the film 'The Musketeer' in the United Kingdom.
The film 'The Musketeer' held its world premiere in Los Angeles on September 5, 2001.
The film 'The Musketeer' held its European premiere at the Deauville Festival on September 7, 2001.
The association between 'The Musketeer' and 'Musketeers of the Guard' is only loosely related.
Vianden Castle is known as Duchamps Castle in the film 'The Musketeer'.
The film 'The Musketeer' used Vianden Castle for its climactic action scene.
The mayor of Viaden was reportedly displeased with damage the castle suffered during filming.
Xin-Xin Xiong was Tim Roth's stunt double in the film 'The Musketeer'.
The film 'The Musketeer' was shown at the American Film Market in the form of a sizzle reel in March 2001.
The film 'The Musketeer' was shown at the American Film Market in March 2001.

The promotional focus on martial arts and extensive trailer rotation ahead of Universal's teen comedy American Pie 2 contributed to the success of this reimagining of Dumas' classic, which was described as 'completely reimagined with fight choreography by Hong Kong legend Xin-Xin Xiong'. However, some industry professionals saw this focus on martial arts as exaggerated and suggested that Universal was overhyping Xiong as a 'legend', as his style owed much to his forebears like Yuen Woo-ping.
This fall, Alexandre Dumas' classic was reimagined as a film with fight choreography by Hong Kong legend Xin-Xin Xiong.
None of the director and stars' names were mentioned in promotional material, indicating that the focus was on the martial arts aspect rather than individual performances.

Trade publication Variety projected that the film would perform respectably in international markets, but suggested that the independent producers might find it hard to break even internationally after selling the U.S. rights for a modest amount.

The film debuted with a $10.7 million opening ahead of Two Can Play That Game and was the number-one film in the country for that weekend before the 9/11 terror attacks. However, the decrease in box office intake was not necessarily due to the terror attacks, as overall box office intake was actually higher year-on-year.
The film grossed $27 million in Canada and the United States.
Internationally, The Musketeer struggled to gross only $7 million.
In France, the country of top billed Catherine Deneuve, it opened on a modest 341 screens for a career tally of 228,037 admissions.
In Germany, which contributed much of the film's budget, theatrical release was compromised by a falling out between distribution partners Helkon and Buena Vista.
Eventually cancelled in favor of a home video premiere nearly two years after its U.S. debut.
The combined worldwide gross of The Musketeer was $34 million.
Against its $36 million production budget.
The film reached number 4 in Billboard's national DVD sales chart.
In Germany, distributor MC One issued a limited and numbered 2-DVD Digipak special edition with a hologram cover and 24-page booklet.
Sales of the film's rights, combined with efficient tax optimization, made The Musketeer a positive venture according to MDP.
Universal also called the film 'a very successful acquisition'.

edge: The film's action focus could be seen as an evolution of the acrobatics seen in Douglas Fairbanks' 1921 and 1929 films.

Decca Records, a subsidiary of Universal Music, was heard on the soundtrack at Universal Studios Florida on September 11, 2001. This suggests a relationship between Decca Records and Universal Music.
The soundtrack featuring Decca Records was frequently heard at the entrance of Universal Studios Florida.
